raw_text:
UK 'world's biggest music buyer'
 
 UK consumers are the biggest music buyers in the world, according to new figures released on Tuesday by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI).
 
 But global sales of recorded music were flat in 2004, with growing sales in DVD music videos offset by online and physical piracy in major markets. The UK music industry recorded an overall 3% increase in volume sales, mostly due to its robust albums market. However, world music sales declined by 1.3% to $33.6 billion (£17.7 billion). The UK CD albums market grew by 4.5% in 2004 with a record 174.6 million units sold. On average every Briton buys 3.2 CDs per person per year.
 
 Around 26,000 albums are released in the UK each year, making Britain second only to the US in terms of the number of releases. Overall sales were driven by new UK-signed artists such as Keane, Katie Melua and Scissor Sisters, whose debut album sold almost 1.6 million copies in the UK. "A slew of great new British artists have met UK music fans' demand for great music," said BPI chairman Peter Jameson. The best-selling album globally was Usher's Confessions - one of eight albums to sell more than five million copies in 2004.
 
 The growth in the DVD market and a sharp increase in sales of digital music ensured a strong market in the US. The total number of tracks downloaded last year were up more than tenfold on 2003. Digital sales in the US in the first two months of 2005 are already more than double that of the same period in 2004.
 
 However, some markets in Continental Europe and Asia - notably Sweden, Finland, France, Spain and South Korea - have been drastically hit by internet piracy. Australia, Italy and the Netherlands also saw a decline. "On the positive side digital sales are booming," said John Kennedy, chief executive of the International Federation of Phonographic Industries (IFPI). "However, commercial piracy and illegal file-sharing are continuing to depress our markets. "The priority in the coming year is to step up the advance of legitimate digital sales and sustain our anti-piracy efforts." "The main choice today's music fan now has to make is whether to get music legally or illegally," added Mr Jameson.
llama3.2:1b: UK consumers are the largest music buyers worldwide, with a 3% increase in album sales.
The UK CD market grew by 4.5%, driven by albums from artists like Keane and Katie Melua.
The industry also saw a boost from new music releases, such as Usher's "Confessions".
However, some markets were affected by internet piracy, including Sweden, Finland, France, Spain, and South Korea.
llama3.2:3b: UK consumers are the biggest music buyers in the world, with 3.2 CDs bought per person per year.
The UK CD albums market grew by 4.5% in 2004, driven by new artists like Keane and Katie Melua.
Global music sales declined by 1.3% to $33.6 billion, affected by piracy in Continental Europe and Asia.
gemma2:2b: UK consumers are the largest music buyers globally, driving a 3% increase in album sales despite flat overall global music revenue.
This growth was driven by new UK artists like Keane and Scissor Sisters.
The US market saw strong growth fueled by DVD and digital music sales.
However, piracy continues to impact markets in Europe and Asia, with download sales surging while illegal sharing remains a challenge.
qwen2.5:0.5b: UK consumers are world's biggest music buyers, but recorded music sales were flat in 2004 with online piracy offset by DVD and physical CDs.
Digital sales have seen an increase and new artists like Usher have been successful.
Some markets worldwide saw a decline in music sales due to internet piracy.
qwen2.5:1.5b: UK consumers are the world's biggest music buyers, with overall volume sales increasing by 3% in 2004 due to robust album market growth and DVD industry expansion offsetting losses from online and physical piracy.

UK releases saw a significant rise in albums (174.6 million units sold) compared to previous years, particularly from new artists like Keane, Katie Melua, and Scissor Sisters who contributed significantly to sales with 1.6 million copies of debut albums sold in the UK.
Digital downloads and increased demand for DVDs supported strong performances in the US market.
However, many countries including Europe and Asia experienced significant declines due to internet piracy.
qwen2.5:3b: UK consumers are the world’s biggest music buyers, with UK sales increasing by 3% in 2004.
Despite flat global recorded music sales ($33.6 billion), the UK saw a 4.5% increase in CD album sales (174.6 million units).
Growth was driven by new UK artists like Keane and Katie Melua, with digital music sales rising significantly in the US.
However, piracy severely impacted markets in Europe and Asia.
In contrast, digital sales are booming globally, though commercial piracy continues to hinder market growth.
opencoder:1.5b: The UK 'world's biggest music buyer' refers to the consumer buying recorded music albums worldwide, primarily in the United Kingdom.
The sales of these albums were highest in 2004 when it witnessed a slight decline, with DVD and online sales offsetting physical sales.
However, global sales grew by about 3%, driven mostly by robust album sales market.
Despite declining sales, new UK-signed artists such as Keane, Melua, Scissor Sisters and the eight albums sold for Usher's Confessions were among the most popular among British music fans.
Competing regions like Sweden, Finland, France, Spain and South Korea witnessed a decline in digital sales.
However, Australia, Italy, and the Netherlands have also seen an increase due to commercial piracy and file-sharing issues which continue to hamper legitimate digital sales.
Overall, despite significant market troubles, the UK music industry remains dominant, with its strong albums market driving sales on several fronts.
Nonetheless, it’s important to note that despite the growing digital sales in the US, international investors may still be cautious about legal piracy.
smollm:1.7b: UK consumers are the biggest music buyers in the world, according to new figures released on Tuesday by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI).
However, global sales of recorded music were flat in 2004, with growing sales in DVD music videos offset by online and physical piracy in major markets.
The UK music industry recorded an overall 3% increase in volume sales, mostly due to its robust albums market.
However, world music sales declined by 1.3% to $33.6 billion (£17.7 billion).
The UK CD albums market grew by 4.5% in 2004 with a record 174.6 million units sold.
On average every Briton buys 3.2 CDs per year.
The best-selling album globally was Usher's Confessions - one of eight albums to sell more than five million copies in 2004.
Around 26,000 albums are released in the UK each year, making Britain second only to the US in terms of the number of releases.
Overall sales were driven by new UK-signed artists such as Keane, Katie Melua and Scissor Sisters, whose debut album sold almost 1.6 million copies in the UK.
"A slew of great new British artists have met UK music fans' demand for great music," said BPI chairman Peter Jameson.
The best-selling album globally was Usher's Confessions - one of eight albums to sell more than five million copies in 2004.
The growth in the DVD market and a sharp increase in sales of digital music ensured a strong market in the US.
The total number of tracks downloaded last year were up more than tenfold on 2003.
Digital sales in the US in the first two months of 2005 are already more than double that of the same period in 2004.
However, some markets in Continental Europe and Asia - notably Sweden, Finland, France, Spain and South Korea - have been devastated by internet piracy.
"On the positive side digital sales are booming," said John Kennedy, chief executive of the International Federation of Phonographic Industries (IFPI).
"However, commercial piracy and illegal file-sharing are continuing to depress our markets."
The main choice today's music fan now has to make is whether to get music legally or illegally.
"On the one hand you have the option to buy a physical album from your local record store," said Mr Jameson.
"On the other hand, you can download it for free on the internet and share it with your friends."
The IFPI estimates that 80% of all music sales in 2004 were illegal downloads.
"We need to take action to protect our markets from this scourge," said Mr Jameson.
"We will continue to work closely with governments, industry bodies and civil society to combat piracy and ensure that the music industry is protected."
The main challenge facing the IFPI in the coming year is to step up the advance of legitimate digital sales and sustain its anti-piracy efforts.
"We need to make sure that our markets are not being exploited by pirates," said Mr Jameson.
"We will work with governments, industry bodies and civil society to ensure that our music fans have access to great music in a legal and sustainable way."
deepseek-r1:1.5b: The UK is the world's largest music buyer with robust sales of CDs, accounting for a 4.5% annual increase across 26,000 releases.
New artists like Keane and Katie Melua have sold well.
Piracy remains a challenge in some markets, while piracy in the US via digital sales has boosted sales.
tinyllama:1.1b: British consumers were the biggest music buyers in the world according to new figures released by the British Phonic Industry (BPI).
In addition, global sales of recorded music were flat, with growing sales in DVD music videos offsetting online and physical piracy in major market sectors.
The UK music industry recorded an overall 3% increase in volume sales, mostly due to robust albums markets.
However, world music sales declined by 1.3% to $33.6 billion (£17.7 billion) in 2004, with CDs accounting for the bulk of this year's growth.
Around 26,000 albums are releaced in the UK each year, making Britain second only to the US in terms of number of releases.
The BPI chairman, Peter Jameson, stated that "the main choice today's music fan now has to make is whether to get music legally or illegaally."
tinydolphin:1.1b: The UK is currently the world's largest music buyer, according to recent figures released by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI).
This means that music consumers in the country spend an incredible amount of money on albums, CDs and other physical formats, as well as purchasing digital tracks.
The BPI recorded a 3% increase in volume sales in 2004, which translates to approximately 175 million units sold worldwide.
This growth can be attributed to the popularity of albums from British artists such as Usher, Keane and Scissor Sisters.
Other popular British acts include Duran Duran, Kiki Dee, and Westlife.
The UK is also home to a large number of established artists, with new releases from these bands selling nearly 1.6 million copies per year on average.
This high level of sales indicates that the UK music industry is attracting some of the most talented musicians in the world.
However, it's important to remember that the figures are just estimates and actual sales figures can vary widely based on the type of album or track being sold.
The CD format has become increasingly popular among consumers, as evidenced by the growth in volume sales.
In 2004, the UK CD albums market saw an increase of almost 4.5%.
However, this is not a reflection of overall growth but rather of the number of releases in that year.
Overall, sales were driven by new artists and by artists signed by British labels like Island Records or Polydor Records.
The BPI highlights that many more albums are being released each year than ever before, with an average of 3.2 CDs sold per person per year.
This suggests that there is a growing demand for great music in the UK and that new artists are proving to be a significant source of growth.

In summary, the UK is currently the largest music buyer on the planet, and despite some challenges related to digital piracy and commercial piracy, there has been an overall increase in sales over the past few years.
phi:2.7b: UK consumers are the biggest music buyers in the world, with a robust albums market driven by new UK-signed artists like Keane, Katie Melua, and Scissor Sisters.
Digital sales have also seen significant growth, with some markets like Sweden, Finland, France, Spain, and South Korea hit hard by internet piracy.
The IFPI warns of continuing to fight against commercial piracy and illegal file-sharing.
orca-mini:3b: The UK was the world's biggest music buyer in 2004, according to new figures released by the British Phonographic Industry (BPI).
hermes3:3b: UK has largest music buyers, with consumers being world's biggest music purchasers, according to BPI figures.
UK CD albums market grew by 4.5%, while global music sales flat in 2004.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: UK consumers are the largest music purchasers globally, with flat global recorded music sales in 2004.
The UK music industry experienced a 3% volume sales increase due to robust album sales, driven by new British artists such as Keane and Scissor Sisters.
US market growth came from DVD music video sales and digital music downloads.
However, some European and Asian markets were negatively impacted by piracy.
Both commercial piracy and illegal file-sharing are depressingly affecting music sales, with a focus on advancing legitimate digital sales in the coming year.
chatgpt-4o-latest: UK consumers are the world's biggest music buyers, according to the British Phonographic Industry (BPI).
While global recorded music sales remained flat in 2004 due to piracy, the UK market grew by 3%, driven by strong album sales, with 174.6 million CDs sold.
The UK releases around 26,000 albums annually, second only to the US, and new UK artists like Keane and Scissor Sisters contributed to sales growth.
Usher's *Confessions* was the best-selling album globally.
The US market saw a surge in digital music sales, while piracy severely impacted markets in Europe and Asia.
Industry leaders emphasize the need to boost legal digital sales and combat piracy.
stablelm2:1.6b: UK consumers are the largest music buyers globally, according to BPI figures.
However, global recorded music sales were flat, with DVD music video sales offsetting online and physical piracy in major markets.
The UK music industry experienced an overall 3% increase in volume sales, mainly due to robust album sales.
New UK-signed artists like Keane, Katie Melua, and Scissor Sisters contributed significantly to the strong market.
The best-selling album globally was Usher's Confessions.
Some European and Asian markets faced significant impacts from internet piracy, while the US saw growth in DVD and digital music markets.
Digital sales continue to boom worldwide but must be legitimized and anti-piracy efforts are crucial for sustained success.
granite3.1-dense:2b: UK consumers lead global recorded music purchases, with a 3% increase in 2004, mainly due to strong album sales and a record 174.6 million CDs sold.
The UK accounts for approximately 3.2 CDs per person annually, with around 26,000 album releases yearly, second only to the US in artist output.
Notable UK artists' debuts include Keane, Katie Melua, and Scissor Sisters, who sold nearly 1.6 million copies each.

Global sales of recorded music were flat in 2004, offset by growth in DVD music videos and declines from online and physical piracy in major markets like the US, Continental Europe, and Asia (Sweden, Finland, France, Spain, and South Korea).
Digital music sales surged more than tenfold in 2004 but remained stagnant in some regions.
The International Federation of Phonographic Industries (IFPI) chief noted that digital sales are booming, but commercial piracy continues to negatively impact markets.
The primary choice for today's music fan is between acquiring music legally or illegally through file-sharing and piracy.
